Ammonia decomposition is a structure-sensitive reaction, so the difference in structure of similar catalysts may have a great impact on the catalytic performance of ammonia decomposition reaction. However, it is not clear which structural properties can play a role in ammonia decomposition reaction and the degree of influence on catalytic performance. To explore this question, ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal (AEH), impregnation (IM), and evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) methods were used to synthesize Ni/SiO2 catalysts to obtain carbon-free hydrogen from catalyzing NH3 decomposition reaction. Among the three, the Ni/SiO2 catalyst synthesized via ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal method is the smallest in terms of Ni nanoparticles (∼3.0 nm) and the strongest Ni-SiO2 interaction. For ammonia decomposition, it is the highest in activity and thermal stability. The NH3 conversion at 650 °C and 30 000 mL gcat −1h−1 (GHSV) over Ni/SiO2-AEH was close to 90 % and remained stable in an evaluation period of 60 h. Hydrogen (H2) is a promising candidate because it is carbon-free and can be used in fuel cells with high efficiency [1,2]. However, due to the low volumetric energy density and explosive nature of H2, its storage and transportation are challenging [3–5]. Hydrogen generation from ammonia is viewed as one of the most promising routes due to the unique nature of ammonia [6]. Ammonia is of high H2 content (17.6 wt%), high volume energy density (22.5 MJ/kg@22 bar), and is easy to liquefy [7]. Ammonia synthesis technology has been ripening for over 100 years and the annual production of ammonia is more than 200 million tons all over the world [8,9]. Hydrogen generated from ammonia decomposition (2NH3(g) ⇋ N2(g) + 3 H2(g)) is carbon-free [10,11]. However, without a catalyst, the operation temperature is high. Therefore, it is necessary to develop materials that can efficiently catalyze ammonia decomposition at low temperatures [12]. Ru and Ni are the two active metals widely used in ammonia decomposition [13–16]. Despite the Ru-based catalysts were found highly active [12], the exorbitant price of Ru metal makes their commercialization uneconomical. Therefore, much research emphasis has been focused on Ni-based catalysts [17–20]. The apparent activation energies (Ea) for NH3 decomposition presented by Yin et al. of supported nickel catalysts are between 80 and 90 kJ/mol, and nickel wires (209 kJ/mol) and nickel films (180 kJ/mol) have much higher energy densities [21], suggesting that the support of Ni on a suitable material is a research direction [22]. For ammonia decomposition, the Ni-based catalysts work on temperatures exceeding 600 °C, and catalyst deactivation because of aggregation of Ni particles is a severe problem [23]. For catalysts that use metals as active sites, the catalytic performance is usually affected by two critical factors, which are the metal nanoparticle size [24] and the strength of interaction between metal and carrier [25,26]. It is hence essential to find ways to inhibit the sintering and growth of nanoparticles. According to Waldvogel et al., the dispersion of active metals, surface area, reducibility and metal- support interaction of a Ni-based catalyst can be well controlled by adjusting the methods for catalyst fabrication [27]. In order to investigate the influence of catalyst structure, we tried to find a support with easy to regulate the structure for loading nickel metal. For heterogeneous catalysis, catalyst supports are commonly made from SiO2 [28–30]. There have been many researches on Ni/SiO2 catalysts for ammonia decomposition. A simple and green synthesis method of Ni/SiO2 ammonia decomposition catalyst was employed by Chen et al., and the effect of pH values and hydrothermal treatment time on catalytic materials in the preparation process was explored [29]. It was concluded that the texture characteristics [31], the Ni nanoparticle size [32], and the interaction between nickel and carrier all contribute to catalyze ammonia decomposition. It was reported that the ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal (AEH) method is an efficient way to gain metal in which the particle size is small and the interaction strength between metal and carrier is strong, mainly due to the formation of phyllosilicate in the precursor and the in situ exsolution of metal under reducing atmosphere [33]. In the previous work, researchers demonstrated that strong metal-support interaction can effectively enhance the catalytic performance of Ni-based ammonia decomposition reaction catalysts, such as Ni/ Al-Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 and Ni/CeO2 catalysts [34,35]. However, there is a lack of consensus on the optimal metal-support interaction strength, and the need for a more detailed understanding of the underlying mechanism. In this work, the ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal (AEH) was applied to synthesize Ni/SiO2 sample with specific structures, and the catalysts synthesized by a modified evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) and impregnation (IM) methods were employed for comparison. The chemical and physical natures of the as-prepared catalysts were manifested by infrared spectroscopy (IR), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) techniques. The Ni-SiO2 interaction was investigated by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and nitrogen temperature-programmed desorption (N2-TPD); and the catalysts were evaluated with respect to ammonia decomposition. The structure–activity relationship of the three Ni/SiO2 catalysts were debated in the field of texture characteristic, metal-to-support interaction and metal particle size. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Materials Nickel (II) nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O), silica sol (30 wt%), tetraethoxysilane (TEOS), Pluronic triblock copolymer P123, aqueous solution of ammonia (NH3·H2O, 25–28 wt%) and anhydrous ethanol were obtained from commercial providers and used without further purification. 2.1.2 Synthesis When came to direct comparison, Ni loading was fixed at two weight percent for all three Ni/SiO2 catalysts. Ni/SiO2-AEH catalysts with other nickel loadings were prepared for the detection of nickel phyllosilicate in XRD analysis (Fig. S1). The Ni/SiO2-AEH sample was prepared via ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal (AEH) method. The solution contained Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (0.5 g), ammonia aqueous solution (5 mL) and deionized water (45 mL) were stirred for half an hour; whereafter, adding silica sol (16.3 g) and stirring at room temperature for another four hours. Afterwards, for vaporizing ammonia, the suspension was heated at 348 K until pH 7 was achieved. After that, the mixed liquor was put into an autoclave lined with Teflon and heated to 423 K for 24 h. Waiting until it cooled naturally to ambient temperature, this precipitation was obtained and washed repeatedly; after drying for four hours at 393 K, the sample went through a calcination process for four hours at 1073 K in static air. The material obtained here was referred as NiO/SiO2-AEH, which then went through a reduction process at 1073 K in 50 vol% hydrogen-nitrogen mixture for three hours to obtain a sample which is denoted as Ni/SiO2-AEH. An impregnation (IM) method was used to synthesize Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst. The SiO2 support is prepared according to the following steps: ammonia aqueous solution (5 mL) and silica sol (16.3 g) were mixed and stirred at room temperature for four hours. Afterwards, for vaporizing ammonia, the suspension was heated at 348 K until pH 7 was achieved. The mixed liquor was put into an autoclave lined with Teflon and heated to 423 K for 24 h. Waiting until it cooled naturally to ambient temperature, this precipitation was obtained and washed repeatedly; after drying for four hours at 393 K, the sample went through a calcination process for four hours at 1073 K in static air. The SiO2 support was obtained by following the above steps. In the meantime, a nickel nitrate solution was obtained by mixing Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (0.50 g) and a suitable amount of deionized water, which was then dropped onto the prepared SiO2 with stirring. After drying for four hours at 393 K, the resulted mixture went through a calcination process for four hours at 1073 K in static air. The material obtained here was referred to as NiO/SiO2-IM. Then the NiO/SiO2-IM material went through a reduction process at 1073 K in 50 vol% hydrogen-nitrogen mixture for three hours to obtain a catalyst which was referred to as Ni/SiO2-IM. The Ni/SiO2-EISA catalyst was prepared by a modified evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) measure [36]. Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (0.50 g) and P123 (9.40 g) and anhydrous ethanol (15 mL) were mixed and the mixture was stirred fully for about four hours. Thereafter, another 2 h were spent stirring continuously the above solution to dissolve the TEOS (16.99 g). At ambient temperature, the homogeneous solution was gelled in a petri dish (D = 0.1 m) for 24–48 h. In order to evaporate the solvent residue from the rigid gel, it was baked at 353 K for more than 12 h. The sample was acquired after the calcination of the dried gel at 1073 K (2 K/min) for four hours in static air using a tube furnace, which was denoted as NiO/SiO2-EISA. The calcination atmosphere was reductive in the study of Xu et al. [36], so the nickel element in the calcined catalysts was in metallic state. We changed the calcination gas to static air to burn away the carbon in the template so as to eliminate the interference of C element; the purpose is to facilitate a comparison with the samples generated by the other two synthesis methods. Then NiO/SiO2-EISA went through a reduction process at 1073 K in 50 vol% hydrogen-nitrogen mixture for three hours to obtain a catalyst which was referred to as Ni/SiO2-EISA. 2.2 Characterizations After sample outgassing at 573 K in vacuum for 4 h, nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurement was taken at 77 K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. To investigate the structural details of the precursors and catalysts, nitrogen adsorption-desorption, XRD, IR and TEM measurement were used. Fixing the Ni loading of the three catalysts to ca. 2 wt% is to ensure a fair dispersion comparison of the Ni species. The three preparation methods have obvious differences in preparation ways and specific illustration is shown in Scheme 1. The precursor of NiO/SiO2-AEH catalyst underwent mixing, ammonia evaporation, hydrothermal treatment, and calcination processes. The ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal method was employed to form nickel-ammine complex ([Ni(NH3)4]2+) by nickel nitrate and ammonia water, and reacted with the support silica in the process of ammonia evaporation to form the structure of Ni phyllosilicate and surface Ni-O-Si. The NiO/SiO2-EISA precursor underwent mixing, induced self-assembly treatment, and calcination processes. The advantage of this method is that the specific surface area of the precursor obtained by roasting is greatly increased by the addition of a template (P123). The NiO/SiO2-IM precursor underwent impregnation and calcination processes. The advantage of this preparation method is that the synthesis process is very simple. The nickel loadings as determined by ICP-AES characterization (in terms of Ni metal) of the three catalysts are close to the nominal values of 2.0 wt%. There are great differences in the structure of the three samples in the calcined state. In terms of specific surface area, due to the addition of a template agent, NiO/SiO2-EISA sample has the largest specific surface area (487 m2 g−1), followed by NiO/SiO2-AEH sample (196 m2 g−1), and NiO/SiO2-IM sample has the smallest specific surface area (10 m2 g−1). To demonstrate the nickel phyllosilicate structure and the surface Ni-O-Si structure only in NiO/SiO2-AEH sample, XRD and IR measurements were carried out. The XRD patterns of the NiO/SiO2 precursors are shown in Fig. 1a. For the NiO/SiO2-AEH sample, the broad peak at 22° is attributable to amorphous silica (labeled “•”) [39]. The characteristic diffraction peaks of NiO are not detected, suggesting that the metal species are uniformly dispersed and small in crystal size. When the metal loadings was gradually risen to 10 wt% (Fig. 1b), the diffraction peaks strength of nickel phyllosilicate [40] (labeled “♦”) at 26.7°, 33.7°, 39.7°, 53.2° and 60.9° increased obviously, confirming that Ni phyllosilicate is formed in the NiO/SiO2-AEH sample. For the NiO/SiO2-EISA and NiO/SiO2-IM precursors, diffraction peaks ascribable to NiO (labeled “▲”) can be observed, indicating that metal species are in the shape of NiO. The intensity of the NiO signals of NiO/SiO2-IM are well above those of Ni/SiO2-EISA, implying that NiO of larger crystallite sizes are synthesized in the former. Furthermore, some amorphous silica has grown into hexagonal silica in NiO/SiO2-EISA and NiO/SiO2-IM precursors. Fig. 1c exhibits the Infrared spectra of the NiO/SiO2 precursors. Those peaks at ca. 1115/1051 cm−1 are attributed to υSiO asymmetric stretching vibrational, the peak at ca. 800 cm−1 is assigned to υSiO symmetric stretching vibrational, and the peak at 1023 cm−1 belongs to the υSiO shoulder. The peak at 671 cm−1 belongs to the δOH bond, which evidences the existence of nickel phyllosilicate [40–42]. As presented in IR spectra of the precursors, the peak at 671 cm−1 is only detected for Ni/SiO2-AEH. Therefore, nickel phyllosilicate species can only be generated when the AEH method is applied, which is essential for strengthening the interaction between Ni and SiO2 after reduction [40,43]. After a unified reduction process, the structure of the catalyst has some changes. In terms of specific surface area, there is a slight loss of specific surface area (SBET) from 196 to 190 m2 g−1 after the reduction of NiO/SiO2-AEH to Ni/SiO2-AEH, plausibly due to the conversion of layered nickel silicate to Ni and SiO2 [33]. However, after the reduction of NiO/SiO2-EISA, there is a substantial decrease of SBET, ascribable to the process of NiO is reduced to Ni as well as the slight aggregation of SiO2 when subject to high temperature treatment. This could be validated by the decrease of the pore volume. As indicated in Fig. 2(c)(f)(i), the Ni nanoparticles in Ni/SiO2-AEH and Ni/SiO2-EISA are evenly dispersed on silica, while those in the Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst are larger in sizes. As demonstrated in Fig. 2(a)(d)(g), the nanoparticle size distribution of nickel was plotted. The Ni nanoparticle size of Ni/SiO2-AEH is ∼3.0 nm and the smallest among the three catalysts. For Ni/SiO2-AEH and Ni/SiO2-IM samples, the difference in Ni nanoparticle size may be due the former SiO2 support is much larger in specific surface area, which is more conducive to the nickel nanoparticles dispersion. For Ni/SiO2-AEH and Ni/SiO2-EISA catalysts, they are rather similar in physical properties, and the reason why the nickel nanoparticle size of Ni/SiO2-EISA is slightly bigger than that of Ni/SiO2-AEH needs further exploration (vide infra). 3.2 Catalytic performance Through a series of characterization on the structure of catalysts prepared by the three different methods, it can be preliminarily judged that the preparation method has a great difference in various structural properties. In order to further explore the influence of the preparation methods on the catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition, we conducted the following catalytic activity tests. Catalytic performances of the Ni/SiO2 samples for ammonia decomposition were measured at a GHSV of 30 000 mL gcat −1h−1 between 400 °C and 750 °C ( Fig. 3a). Increasing reaction temperatures increase ammonia conversion, which is consistent with endothermic nature of ammonia decomposition reaction. The Ni/SiO2-AEH catalyst exhibits the highest activity, giving a NH3 conversion of 99.5 % at 700 °C, close to the equilibrium NH3 conversion at 700 °C, whereas the NH3 conversion over Ni/SiO2-EISA and Ni/SiO2-IM is 77 % and 26 %, respectively. The absence of diffusion limitations are confirmed by the estimated Weisz-Prater Criterion (C WP) for Internal Diffusion and Mears’ Criterion (C M) for External Diffusion [37]. As C WP = 1.52 × 10–4 < 1 and C M = 7.0 × 10–6 < 0.15, the internal and external diffusion effects could be neglected during the kinetic experiments [38]. According to the Arrhenius plots, the apparent activation energies (Ea) of Ni/SiO2 samples exhibited in Fig. 3b exhibit an incremental sequence of Ni/SiO2-AEH (77.3 kJ/mol) < Ni/SiO2-EISA (91.4 kJ/mol) < Ni/SiO2-IM (108.3 kJ/mol), and catalytic activities were arranged in a good manner in accordance with this order (Fig. 3a). The activation energy for the general Ni-based catalyst is 111–113 kJ/mol [44], which is consistent with the result of the Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst. The reduction of activation energies of Ni/SiO2-AEH and Ni/SiO2-EISA catalysts may be due to the decrease in crystallite size and particle size. When catalyst particles are too large, reactants may have difficulty diffusing into the interior of the particle where the catalytic reaction occurs. This can lead to lower reaction rates and incomplete conversion of reactants. By reducing the size of the catalyst particles, the diffusion path length is shortened, allowing more efficient mass transport of reactants to the catalytic sites within the particle. The effect of catalyst particle size on the reaction rate needs to be justified based on the principles of mass transport and reaction kinetics. Specifically, it can be shown that smaller catalyst particles can provide higher reaction rates due to increased surface area per unit volume. This leads to a greater number of active sites available for reaction and a higher probability of reactant molecules colliding with these sites. However, excessively small particle sizes may also lead to other issues such as increased susceptibility to sintering or agglomeration, which can decrease the catalytic activity over time. Therefore, an optimal catalyst particle size should be chosen based on a balance between these factors, as well as practical considerations such as catalyst production cost and stability under operating conditions. Ammonia decomposition is a typical endothermic reaction, and high temperatures help the reaction to proceed forward. However, high reaction temperatures are not only energy consuming, but also lead to agglomeration of metallic Ni0 nanoparticles, resulting in catalyst deactivation. As displayed in Fig. 3c, the Ni/SiO2-AEH catalyst shows only slight decrease of NH3 conversion in a run of 50 h, while the decrease of ammonia conversion over Ni/SiO2-EISA is much more significant. The ammonia conversion over Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst is low throughout the 50 h test. The calculated results of H2 formation rates are plotted in Fig. 3d. There is a slight increase in hydrogen formation rate for Ni/SiO2-AEH compared to Ni/SiO2-EISA, and a significant increase for Ni/SiO2-IM. The hydrogen generation rate is 9.6 mmol gcat −1 min−1 over Ni/SiO2-AEH at 550 °C, which has much higher rate compared with many nickel-based catalysts at this temperature, such as Ni/TiO2 (2.0 mmol gcat −1 min−1), Ni/SrTiO3 (5.4 mmol gcat −1 min−1) and Ni/BaZrO3 (6.3 mmol gcat −1 min−1) [18]. 3.3 Understanding of the structure-performance relationship and reaction mechanism In catalytic reaction, the texture properties of catalyst have critical influence on mass transfer; for example, big pore size and large specific surface area are critical factors for the increasement of catalytic activity. For NH3 decomposition, the results of the experiment and theory suggested that with the average pore size of a catalyst is smaller than 7.7 nm, the diffusion of NH3 molecules in Ni/SiO2 catalyst is dominated by Knudsen diffusion. [31] When the average pore size is larger than 16.6 nm, the diffusion of NH3 is dominated by both Knudsen diffusion and molecular diffusion, leading to lower diffusion resistance. As summarized in Table 1, the average pore size of Ni/SiO2-AEH catalyst is higher than 16.6 nm, while those of Ni/SiO2-EISA (4.5 nm) and Ni/SiO2-IM (12.1 nm) are lower, suggesting that the N2 and NH3 diffusion resistances among the three are different from one another. Consequently, the variation of average pore sizes among the three Ni/SiO2 catalysts could have an effect on catalytic performance. The texture characteristics, for instance pore size, specific surface area and other texture properties could affect the surface diffusion of reactant, intermediates and products. The Ni/SiO2-EISA sample has the largest specific surface area because of the import of template agent. The surface area of Ni/SiO2-AEH is only 196 m2 g−1, which is 2.5 times lower than that of Ni/SiO2-EISA. Generally, catalysts with large specific surface area possess higher catalytic activity because the large specific surface area facilitates the dispersion of active metal and the transport of reaction molecules. Indeed, the Ni/SiO2-EISA catalyst is the catalyst with the highest amount of nitrogen desorption, but not the lowest desorption temperature. However, ammonia decomposition performance of Ni/SiO2-AEH sample is significantly better than that of Ni/SiO2-EISA sample, indicating that specific surface area is not the decisive element influencing the catalytic decomposition of ammonia. In addition, the surface and bulk phase properties of the SiO2 carriers in the catalysts prepared by different synthesis methods differed significantly. In the Ni/SiO2-AEH sample, the support is amorphous silica, which is favorable to the dispersion of the active metal; in both Ni/SiO2-EISA and Ni/SiO2-IM samples, the support appears partially hexagonal phase silica, indicating that the support prepared by both synthetic methods has some crystalline phase growth, which further affects the dispersion of the active metal. Another important factor affecting Ni-based catalyst performance is the nickel nanoparticles size. By varying the preparation method, the loading mode of active nickel on the supports varies ( Scheme 2), thus the size of nickel nanoparticles in the samples differs. The Ni nanoparticles of Ni/SiO2-AEH has the smallest size (3.0 nm), and the Ni/SiO2-AEH sample is the highest in catalytic performance towards ammonia decomposition, indicating that the size of active metal nanoparticles has a significant impact on the catalytic reaction. The relationship between the catalytic activity difference from 600 °C to 700 °C and Ni particle size is plotted in Fig. 4. It can be seen that the activity difference decreases with the increase of metal particle size. Between 3 nm and 23 nm, there is a good linear relationship between the activity difference and metal particle size. When Ni particles are less than 3 nm, the activity is predicted to be further improved, but too small particle size is not easy to form the active site of Ni, so the catalytic activity will be reduced. When Ni particles are larger than 23 nm, it is predicted that the catalytic activity will be further reduced. The reducibility of NiO species of the NiO/SiO2 precursors was investigated by H2-TPR. As demonstrated in Fig. 5, peaks at 410 °C and 495 °C are distinct for the Ni/SiO2-EISA and Ni/SiO2-IM samples, respectively. This is a result of NiO being reduced to Ni0 and corresponded to a weak metal-support interaction [45]. The reduction peak of Ni/SiO2-IM is 85 °C (from 410° to 495°C) higher than that of Ni/SiO2-EISA, which can be ascribed to the NiO particles in Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst are larger in size. The reduction of Ni/SiO2-AEH shifts to higher temperature peaked at 705 °C, suggesting that Ni species interact strongly with SiO2 [31,46]. From the above IR and XRD analyses, it is confirmed that there is the existence of nickel phyllosilicate in the NiO/SiO2-AEH precursor, so the reduction peak at high temperature can be put down to the process that Ni2+ in nickel phyllosilicate is reduced to Ni0. The TEM results (Fig. 2a and d) exhibit that the size of nickel nanoparticles of Ni/SiO2-EISA is a bit bigger than that of Ni/SiO2-AEH, which may be due to the fact that the Ni nanoparticles of the former has weaker interaction with the SiO2 support during high-temperature reduction. The possible rate-determining steps of NH3 decomposition may be the formation of N-N bond and desorption of N2 [47]. Therefore, the desorption temperature of N2 molecules is closely related to the rate of ammonia decomposition. To explore the reason for the differences in catalytic performance among the three catalysts, we employed the N2-TPD characterization technique, and the N2-TPD profiles are depicted in Fig. 5. Nitrogen molecules are very stable with high NN bonding energy and the nitrogen adsorbed by the catalyst at low temperatures is mostly in the form of physical adsorption. To obtain significant chemisorption of nitrogen at the active site, the nitrogen adsorption temperature was raised to 500 °C. A weak N2 desorption peak at about 366 °C is collected for each of the three catalysts, which can be put down to the desorption of nitrogen with weak interaction with the catalysts. There is strong N2 desorption at much higher temperature across the three catalysts, with desorption starting at around 648, 716 and 818 °C for Ni/SiO2-AEH, Ni/SiO2-IM and Ni/SiO2-EISA, respectively. The N2 desorption of the catalysts locates at high temperatures (> 600 °C) can be attributed to chemisorbed nitrogen. The difference in their temperatures represents the difference in the difficulty of desorption of the chemisorbed nitrogen in those catalysts. This means that the desorption of N adatoms from Ni/SiO2-AEH is much easier than that from Ni/SiO2-EISA. The ease of N2 desorption is beneficial to freeing the active sites from being occupied by N adatoms to promote the forward reaction [48], so the Ni/SiO2-AEH catalyst is the best among the three in catalytic performance. The chemical states of Ni species in the NiO/SiO2 precursors (Fig. 5c) and Ni/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 5d) were measured by XPS. For oxidation state confirmation, the Ni 2p3/2 peaks at 854.1 eV and 856.5 eV are assigned to Ni2+ and Ni3+ species, respectively [36]. After careful examination of the peak areas between the Ni2+ and Ni3+ species in Fig. 5d, it is concluded that the surface of Ni/SiO2-AEH catalyst is dominated by Ni3+ species; that of Ni/SiO2-EISA catalyst is mainly made up of Ni3+ species and a certain amount of Ni2+ species; while the surface of Ni/SiO2-IM sample is predominated by Ni2+ species. The presence of Ni3+ species indicates that the –O–Ni–O–Si–O– chemical bonds form, indicating dispersed nickel phyllosilicate had been formed on the surface of Ni/SiO2-AEH catalyst [49,50]. After reduction, the Ni 2p3/2 profiles can be deconvoluted into 4 peaks (Fig. 5d). The peak at 861.1 eV can be assigned to Ni2+ satellite peak; peaks at 853.1, 854.9 and 856.5 eV can be attributed to Ni0, Ni2+ and Ni3+ species, respectively [36]. The Ni 2p3/2 binding energy at 856.5 eV approaches that of nickel silicate (Ni2SiO4) at 856.3 eV, which indicates that there is a strong chemical Ni-SiO2 bond [36]. Therefore, based on the XPS results, it is inferred that the Ni-SiO2 interaction strength follows the sequence of Ni/SiO2-AEH > Ni/SiO2-EISA > Ni/SiO2-IM, which accords with the results of H2-TPR study (Fig. 5a). Moreover, for all the three catalysts, there are still Ni2+ species after the reduction treatment, which indicates that not all of the oxidized nickel species on the surface of catalysts go through a reduction process to metallic state. The existence of chemical –O–Ni–O–Si–O– bonding of nickel, oxygen and silicon can provide a basis to argue that there is a strong Ni-SiO2 interaction on the surface of Ni/SiO2-AEH sample, which leads to improvement of the catalytic activity and stability. The XRD and IR characterization results confirm that the metal species exist in the form of Ni phyllosilicate in the NiO/SiO2-AEH sample, whereas the nickel species exist in the form of NiO in the NiO/SiO2-EISA and NiO/SiO2-IM precursors. The nickel species in the NiO/SiO2-AEH catalyst have SMSI due to the chemical –O–Ni–O–Si–O– bonding, which can be illustrated by the shift of H2-TPR peak position towards high temperature. The strong interaction stems the sintering and growth of Ni0 particles at high temperatures. Hence, the Ni/SiO2-AEH sample is superior to the Ni/SiO2-EISA sample in performance. The combinative desorption of nitrogen adatoms is commonly considered as the rate determining step of NH3 decomposition reaction. The nitrogen desorption temperature of Ni/SiO2-AEH sample is greatly lower than that of Ni/SiO2-EISA sample, so the former has lower apparent activation energy and better catalytic activity, which can be verified by the results derived from the Arrhenius plots of the Ni/SiO2 samples. For the fabrication of Ni/SiO2 samples, the synthesis methods affect the structural properties, including texture characteristics, Ni nanoparticle size and Ni-SiO2 interaction. As shown in the characterization results of this work, the Ni particles size and the intensity of Ni-SiO2 interaction play key roles in catalyzing the ammonia decomposition reaction. Being the smallest in Ni nanoparticle size and the strongest interaction between metal and support, the Ni/SiO2-AEH sample is the best in catalytic performance and thermal stability. Nitrogen recombination desorption is considered to be the rate-determining step of ammonia decomposition, so the rate of nitrogen decomposition is very important for the forward progression of the reaction. It can be seen from the results of N2-TPD that the desorption capacity of the three catalysts for N2 is very different, among which AEH sample is the strongest, IM sample is the worst. It can be seen from the kinetic test results that the activation energy of the IM sample is 108.3 kJ/mol, which is similar to that of the ordinary supported Ni/SiO2 catalysts. For AEH catalyst, the activation energy is significantly reduced to 77.3 kJ/mol, indicating that the recombination desorption of N * plays an important role in promoting the ammonia decomposition reaction. Ni-based catalyst induced by nickel phyllosilicate as precursor show high catalytic performance. On the one hand, Ni metal particles obtained from in-situ reduction can exist in the state of small particle size and high dispersion, so that more active sites can be exposed in the catalytic reaction than Ni metal with large particle size, as to improve the intrinsic catalytic performance. On the other hand, Ni particles obtained from in-situ exsolution can exist stably at high temperature, showing strong resistance to sintering and growth, which can greatly improve the stability. In this work, we prepared three Ni/SiO2 ammonia decomposition catalysts with different factors that can affect catalytic activity, including specific surface area, metal particle size, metal-support interaction, etc. The experimental results show that metal particle size and metal-support interaction play decisive roles in the catalytic ammonia decomposition performance. We hope that this result can serve as a guide for the subsequent preparation of catalysts. 4 Conclusions Three routes were used for the preparation of Ni/SiO2 catalysts for ammonia decomposition. The Ni/SiO2-AEH catalyst, which has the smallest size (3.0 nm) of Ni nanoparticles and the strongest Ni-SiO2 interaction strength, exhibited the best catalytic performance and thermal stability, and the ammonia conversion at 650 °C was close to 90 % at a GHSV of 30 000 mL gcat −1h−1. The size of Ni nanoparticles of the Ni/SiO2-EISA catalyst was also small, but the intensity of Ni-SiO2 interaction was much weaker, resulting in poor catalytic stability. With Ni nanoparticles unevenly dispersed and much larger in size, the Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst showed the lowest catalytic activity among the three catalysts. It is concluded that the size of Ni particles and the strength of metal-support interaction are the critical factors affecting the ammonia decomposition reaction. coredata.dc:description: Ammonia decomposition is a structure-sensitive reaction, so the difference in structure of similar catalysts may have a great impact on the catalytic performance of ammonia decomposition reaction. However, it is not clear which structural properties can play a role in ammonia decomposition reaction and the degree of influence on catalytic performance. To explore this question, ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal (AEH), impregnation (IM), and evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) methods were used to synthesize Ni/SiO2 catalysts to obtain carbon-free hydrogen from catalyzing NH3 decomposition reaction. Among the three, the Ni/SiO2 catalyst synthesized via ammonia evaporation-hydrothermal method is the smallest in terms of Ni nanoparticles (∼3.0 nm) and the strongest Ni-SiO2 interaction. For ammonia decomposition, it is the highest in activity and thermal stability. The NH3 conversion at 650 °C and 30 000 mL gcat −1h−1 (GHSV) over Ni/SiO2-AEH was close to 90 % and remained stable in an evaluation period of 60 h.
